Public transportation facilities have closed down for the
night, the neon-signs are nearly all turned out, and the
enticing shop windows are shuttered with wood and steel.
The streets are cold, lonely and almost frightening. As
all Tokyoites know, the price of land in Ginza is fabulously
high and, in earlier times, people would say that one ”sho"
(about 2 liters) of land was worth one "sho" of money--the
Japanese equivalent of the Western expression "worth its
weight in gold.”
It is natural, therefore, that buildings should cover every
available lot and they should be standing wall to wall.
These tightly packed buildings are deserted when day gives
way to night on the Ginza.

The International Trade Fair is underway at Osaka. In scale
and number of participants (and exhibits) the Fair is twice
as large as its predecessor in 1954. Three thousand entrants
from Japan5 and 20 entrants from foreign countries occupy
1600 exhibition booths.
The current fair is given added significance this year by
the fact that the city of Osaka is now a member of the
International Union of Fairs. This is Japan's first interr
national trade exhibition since the country acquired re¬
presentation in the Paris organization. UFI, by the way,
is made up of 30 permanent trade fairs representing 16
nations.
At this time, I'd like to quote the address of John
Snedaker, President of the American Chamber of Commerce
in Japan. Mr. Snedaker's address is entitled: "Progress
to Plenty—the Aim of this Fair." In fact, this is the
official theme over the American pavillion, written large
over the entrance: PROGRESS TO PLENTY.
